text:
I don't think I have a preference honestly, I love variety! Learning how different things move and finding ways to bring them to life is part of why I love animation.
And about UV's and texturing, It's great to be aware of your weaknesses/ what you find difficult, it becomes more straight forward to practice and improve on it.

So for time management, it's a tricky question. Throughout the week I can have relaxed deadlines and suddenly get a super short one, so I have to adapt depending on the situation.
Firstly I try and prioritize whats most important, I write down bullet points/ checklist of what I need to do, If I see the time isn't enough I immediately flag it to production so they're aware, and find out if I have wiggle room :smiley:
When I was in Uni, I had we had to work on a solo short-film, since I needed to make everything, the most important part was to set realistic goals.
After splitting up my work between hard, medium and easy shots, I could get an idea of how much time a shot would take to animate. So in the beginning of the day, I'd set a goal of what I needed to get done, and I'd try my best to meet it. It was super important to be aware of my capability/ speed, and the more I did it the more I'd know how long something would take.
Does that help in anyway?
